lines.text: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: What a plague means my niece, to take the death of her brother thus? I am sure care's an enemy to life.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o' nights: your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions to your ill hours.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Why, let her except, before excepted.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Ay, but you must confine yourself within the modest limits of order.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Confine! I'll confine myself no finer than I am: these clothes are good enough to drink in; and so be these boots too: an they be not, let them hang themselves in their own straps.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: That quaffing and drinking will undo you: I heard my lady talk of it yesterday; and of a foolish knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Ay, he.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: He's as tall a man as any's in Illyria.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: What's that to the purpose?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Ay, but he'll have but a year in all these ducats: he's a very fool and a prodigal.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Fie, that you'll say so! he plays o' the viol-de-gamboys, and speaks three or four languages word for word without book, and hath all the good gifts of nature.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: He hath indeed, almost natural: for besides that he's a fool, he's a great quarreller: and but that he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he hath in quarrelling, 'tis thought among the prudent he would quickly have the gift of a grave.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: By this hand, they are scoundrels and subtractors that say so of him. Who are they?

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: They that add, moreover, he's drunk nightly in your company.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: With drinking healths to my niece: I'll drink to her as long as there is a passage in my throat and drink in Illyria: he's a coward and a coystrill that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn o' the toe like a parish-top. What, wench! Castiliano vulgo! for here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.
Enter SIR ANDREW

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Sir Toby Belch! how now, Sir Toby Belch!

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Sweet Sir Andrew!

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Bless you, fair shrew.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: And you too, sir.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: What's that?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: My niece's chambermaid.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: My name is Mary, sir.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Good Mistress Mary Accost,--

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: You mistake, knight; 'accost' is front her, board her, woo her, assail her.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: By my troth, I would not undertake her in this company. Is that the meaning of 'accost'?

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Fare you well, gentlemen.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst never draw sword again.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: An you part so, mistress, I would I might never draw sword again. Fair lady, do you think you have fools in hand?

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Sir, I have not you by the hand.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Marry, but you shall have; and here's my hand.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Now, sir, 'thought is free:' I pray you, bring your hand to the buttery-bar and let it drink.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Wherefore, sweet-heart? what's your metaphor?

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: It's dry, sir.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Why, I think so: I am not such an ass but I can keep my hand dry. But what's your jest?

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: A dry jest, sir.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Are you full of them?

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers' ends: marry, now I let go your hand, I am barren.
Exit

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: O knight thou lackest a cup of canary: when did I see thee so put down?

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Never in your life, I think; unless you see canary put me down. Methinks sometimes I have no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man has: but I am a great eater of beef and I believe that does harm to my wit.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: No question.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: An I thought that, I'ld forswear it. I'll ride home to-morrow, Sir Toby.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Pourquoi, my dear knight?

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: What is 'Pourquoi'? do or not do? I would I had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing and bear-baiting: O, had I but followed the arts!

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Why, would that have mended my hair?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Past question; for thou seest it will not curl by nature.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: But it becomes me well enough, does't not?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Excellent; it hangs like flax on a distaff; and I hope to see a housewife take thee between her legs and spin it off.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Faith, I'll home to-morrow, Sir Toby: your niece will not be seen; or if she be, it's four to one she'll none of me: the count himself here hard by woos her.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: She'll none o' the count: she'll not match above her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit; I have heard her swear't. Tut, there's life in't, man.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: I'll stay a month longer. I am a fellow o' the strangest mind i' the world; I delight in masques and revels sometimes altogether.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight?

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the degree of my betters; and yet I will not compare with an old man.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Faith, I can cut a caper.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: And I can cut the mutton to't.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: And I think I have the back-trick simply as strong as any man in Illyria.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Wherefore are these things hid? wherefore have these gifts a curtain before 'em? are they like to take dust, like Mistress Mall's picture? why dost thou not go to church in a galliard and come home in a coranto? My very walk should be a jig; I would not so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace. What dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues in? I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy leg, it was formed under the star of a galliard.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Ay, 'tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a flame-coloured stock. Shall we set about some revels?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: What shall we do else? were we not born under Taurus?

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Taurus! That's sides and heart.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: No, sir; it is legs and thighs. Let me see the caper; ha! higher: ha, ha! excellent!
Exeunt
